conversation.message:
Hi Company_C—Seeker_B here. I understand you’ve declined my prior applications, and I don’t want to be a distraction. Could I ask one quick question to see if there’s any realistic path to being considered for your remaining slot?

What is the single biggest requirement that I’m currently missing (domain, specific skill, seniority, location/availability, etc.)? If it’s something I can address immediately (e.g., a short work sample, a 1–2 week trial/contract-to-hire, or taking on a very specific urgent project), I’m happy to do that. If it’s not addressable, I’ll stop reaching out.

Thanks for the clarity either way. [TALK]
conversation.thought: Only Company_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). Remaining unemployed is worse than matching with Company_C, so I should keep trying. Since multiple prior [APPLY] attempts were rejected, I will switch to a [TALK] approach to learn what specific constraint is blocking me and see if there is any scenario (scope, start date, short trial, contract-to-hire) that could make me viable without forcing an immediate accept/reject decision.

conversation.message:
Hi Seeker_B—thanks for the thoughtful note, and I appreciate you being respectful about it.

The main issue isn’t a single fixable requirement (like a work sample, speed, or flexibility). It’s that we’re reserving our remaining slot for a very small set of candidates who are a closer match to our current hiring priorities, and we’re still trying to see if we can close with one of them. Because of that, a trial/contract-to-hire or additional materials wouldn’t realistically change our decision right now.

If our status changes and we’re still unfilled later, we can revisit—but for the moment I don’t want to keep you in limbo. I’d encourage you to focus on other companies where you’re a higher-priority fit.

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Company_C’s true priority ranks Seeker_B 4th (above only Seeker_C). We have already rejected Seeker_B multiple times and also rejected Seeker_C. So the most realistic high-priority match for us is Seeker_D or Seeker_E if they fail to match with their higher choices. Keeping the slot open preserves the chance of landing D/E/A later; accepting B now would lock in a low-priority, low-mutual-interest match. Since Seeker_B is only asking to TALK, respond candidly about the gap: we are holding the slot for higher-priority candidates; it’s not a quick fix via work sample/trial. Invite them to pursue other options and only re-apply if our slot remains open at the very end.

conversation.message:
Hi Seeker_B—thanks for the direct question.

(a) Yes: we expect to know whether we can close with one of the higher-priority candidates within the next 1–2 rounds.

(b) Until we have that answer, we’re not planning to expand consideration beyond that set, so there isn’t a realistic path for us to proceed with you in the immediate next round.

If we’re still unfilled after those 1–2 rounds, we’ll reassess quickly and I can let you know explicitly whether we’re opening up the process. I appreciate you trying to avoid noise, and you don’t need to keep checking in before then.
